revised_title: Excitability, Conduction, and Coordination of Responses in Rhabdocalyptus Dawsoni
tldr: This study investigates the ability of hexactinellid sponges, specifically Rhabdocalyptus dawsoni, to halt their feeding current when stimulated and how this response is coordinated throughout the sponge. The research focuses on the properties of the conduction system and the characteristics of the arrest response. The findings show that these sponges have a conduction system with excitability properties similar to nerve and muscle, but they do not have a nervous system. The conducting tissue is likely the trabecular net, which is distributed throughout the sponge.
